title: Croatia - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 3 February 2021, thousands of small business owners, mostly from the hospitality industry, protested in Zagreb-Donji Grad, demanding subsidies from the government and to be allowed to open again. Their businesses were forced to close as a measure to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=thousands]

On 1 February 2021, several (not named in the report) civil rights group held a performance in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, to mark a one-year anniversary of protests against the Mayor and to call people to vote against him in the upcoming local election. [size=no report]
On 30 January 2021, around 80 supporters of a football club protested in Vukovar, Croatia, after two other supporters were arrested for allegedly assaulting a police officer. [size=around 80]
On 24 January 2021, around 100 people protested in Dubrovnik, Croatia, in support of a police officer who was fired for sexual harassment during his hearing. [size=around 100]

On 20 January 2021, several dozen members of a football fan group protested in Osijek, Croatia, in front of the jail where 2 of their members are detained after allegedly assaulting a police officer. [size=several dozen]
SDP: Social Democratic Party of Croatia
On 19 January 2021, around 20 SDP activists protested in Pozega, Croatia, against the city's mayor, accusing him of corruption. [size=around 20]
On 9 January 2021, approximately 15 people protested in Pula, Croatia, against epidemiological measures and vaccination, prompted by the coronavirus pandemic. [size=approximately 15]

On 26 December 2020, two unidentified men attempted to set a gay man of fire in Zagreb-Maksimir, Croatia. He believes the only motive for this was his sexual orientation. He was hospitalized with severe burns.
Labour Group (Croatia); Former Military Forces of Croatia (2016-)
Around 21 December 2020, as reported, a group of former port workers, who are also army veterans, protested in in Ploce, Croatia, because they are facing eviction from their homes. [size=no report]

On 19 December 2020, several dozen people protested in Osijek, Croatia, against new lockdown measures, including restrictions of movement. The measures were introduced to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=several dozen]
On 18 December 2020, those who lease business spaces from the city protested in Pula, Croatia, demanding cancellation of rent from the city due to the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 12 December 2020, several dozen people protested in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia. They oppose measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, like mandatory face masks and potentially obligatory vaccination. [size=several dozen]

On 12 December 2020, around a dozen protesters marched through Rijeka, Croatia. They oppose measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, like mandatory face masks and potentially obligatory vaccination. [size=around a dozen]

On 7 December 2020, small entrepreneurs protested in Zagreb-Trnje, demanding help from the government as some are unable to work due to measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 5 December 2020, around 50 people protested against mandatory vaccination for the coronavirus in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia. Counter-protesters were also present. [size=around 50]

On 30 November 2020, between several dozen and several hundred, according to different reports, entrepreneurs and business owners from the hospitality industry marched through Zagreb, Croatia, against new measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus that would restrict their work. [size=between several dozen and several hundred]

On 29 November 2020, coaches and fitness enthusiasts protested the closing of gyms by having a public group exercise in Pula, Croatia. The gyms were closed as a measure to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 29 November 2020, coaches and fitness enthusiasts protested the closing of gyms by having a public group exercise in Rovinj, Croatia. The gyms were closed as a measure to stop the spread of the coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 28 November 2020, approximately 30 people protested in Zagreb-Osijek, Croatia, against measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, calling them ''political repression''. [size=approximately 30]

On 28 November 2020, approximately 15 people protested in Split, Croatia, against measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, calling them ''political repression''. [size=approximately 15]
On 28 November 2020, people protested in Pula, Croatia, against measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, calling them ''political repression''. [size=no report]

On 28 November 2020, approximately 20 people protested in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, against measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, calling them ''political repression''. [size=approximately 20]

On 25 November 2020, teachers protested in Zagreb-Maksimir, Croatia, demanding better working condition, as well as better organization and support for the education system during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
On 23 November 2020, a protest was held in Pula, Croatia, against a planned construction of an Islamic center. The protesters said they only object to the location of the center. [size=no report]
On 15 November 2020, local residents protested in Prezid, Croatia, against recycling waste from Italy being stored in their town. [size=no report]

On 14 November 2020, local residents of Vranjic protested in Split, Croatia, voicing a number of environmental concerns they have about their village, including pollution and oil spills. [size=no report]

On 8 November 2020, approximately 1000 people protested in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, against measures imposed to stop the spread of the coronavirus, like mandatory face masks and potential vaccination. [size=approximately 1000]
On 6 November 2020, local residents protested in Split, Croatia, against turning a playground into a parking lot. [size=no report]
On 3 November 2020, several dozen medical staff protested in Zagreb-Gornja Dubrava, Croatia, against turning their hospital into a coronavirus-only facility. [size=several dozen]
On 30 October 2020, dozens of medical staff protested in Zagreb-Gornja Dubrava, against their hospital being turned into a coronavirus health center, claiming they are understaffed. [size=dozens]

On 26 October 2020, haul truckers protested and blocked traffic in Zagreb, Croatia, with over 150 trucks, claiming the waiting periods at the borders are too long due to the coronavirus. [size=over 150 trucks]

On 19 October 2020, approximately 20 owners and workers of transport companies protested in their vehicles in Dugopolje, Croatia, demanding help as their business suffered due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=approximately 20]
On 17 October 2020, approximately 500 people protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, against the closure of a cult night club. [size=approximately 500]

On 16 October 2020, around 200 local residents protested in Omis, Croatia, demanding a tunnel be opened while the road is under reconstruction, as they have now been advised to use boats for transport. [size=no report]
Police Forces of Croatia (2016-); Government of Croatia (2016-)

On 12 October 2020, one man opened fire on policemen guarding the entrance to the parliament building in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, wounding one of them. The shooter later committed suicide at another location. His social media posts show strong right-wing criticism of the government.

On 12 October 2020, a group of 4 Afghan migrants reported that they were arrested by Croatian police near Novo Selo, Croatia, after they had crossed the border from Bosnia. They were taken away in a van by 10 masked men, who the police called, who then severely beat them, whipped them, and sexually assaulted one of the migrants. The migrants were later pushed back into Bosnia. [size=at least 10]

On 10 October 2020, approximately 100 people protested in Rijeka, Croatia, against masks, restrictions, and other measures imposed against the coronavirus pandemic. They called it the 'Festival of Freedom'. [size=approximately 100]
On 8 October 2020, hairdressers protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, demanding a lower VAT. [size=no report]
On 7 October 2020, around 200 local residents protested and blocked the road in Omis, Croatia, against temporary closure of the main road. [size=around 200]
On 29 September 2020, law students protested in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, after tuition fees increased. [size=no report]
On 26 September 2020, farmers protested in Markusica, Croatia, because of a dispute over agricultural land. [size=no report]
On 26 September 2020, 150 residents of the local neighbourhood protested in Zagreb-Crnomerec, Croatia, against a mobile recycling yard. [size=150]
A-HSP: Autochthonous Croatian Party of Rights

On 26 September 2020, around a dozen members of A-HSP protested in Rijeka, Croatia, after the city mounted a five-point red star to commemorate the liberation after World War 2. Several counter-protesters were also present. [size=about a dozen]
BBC News; Rijeka Novi List Online

On 22 September 2020, about 300 Croatian war veterans protested in Karlovac, Croatia, against the commemoration of the deaths of Serbian prisoners of war killed by Croatian soldiers in 1991. [size=about 300]
On 21 September 2020, approximately 50 shipyard workers protested in Trogir, Croatia, because their wages haven't been paid for several months. [size=approximately 50]
On 20 September 2020, a protest in support of the city mayor was held in Nova Gradiska, Croatia, after the mayor was arrested due to alleged corruption. [size=no report]
On 20 September 2020, several hundred people protested in Rijeka, Croatia, against the city marking the liberation after World War 2 by mounting a five-point red star. [size=several hundred]

On 19 September 2020, approximately 500 people marched through Zagreb, Croatia, in an LGBT+ pride march, demanding a change of constitution so same-sex partnership would be recognized as marriage. [size=approximately 500]

On 19 September 2020, approximately 150 people protested in Varazdin, Croatia, against sexual violence against women, after news broke that a local psychiatrist had been sexually abusing female patients for years. [size=approximately 150]

On 18 September 2020, approximately 30 law students protested in Split, Croatia, because an exam term has been cancelled due to the coronavirus, and in general against the university's response to the pandemic. [size=approximately 30]

On 10 September 2020, Human Shield activists unloaded several dozen water melons in front of the government building in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, to protest import of that fruit. [size=no report]
On 10 September 2020, pyrotechnicians protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, due to budget cuts and firings. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, a group of citizens protested in Split, Croatia, in order to draw attention to the fact that a Roman aqueduct is at risk of collapsing, which would jeopardize the city's water supply. [size=no report]
On 5 September 2020, around 20 people protested in Dubrovnik, Croatia, against the coronavirus prevention measures, calling it the 'Freedom Festival'. [size=around 20]
On 5 September 2020, several hundred people protested in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, against coronavirus prevention measures, calling it the 'Freedom Festival' [size=several hundred]
On 4 September 2020, around 20 workers of a shipyard protested in Trogir, Croatia, because of unpaid wages. [size=around 20]
On 4 August 2020, representatives of pyrotechnicians protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, due to firings in their sector. [size=no report]
On 1 August 2020, approximately 100 citizens protested in Zadar, Croatia, against asbestos waste being stored on a ship permanently docked in their harbour. [size=approximately 100]
On 1 August 2020, approximately 400 local citizens protested in Split, Croatia, against car traffic around their local beach. [size=approximately 400]

On 30 July 2020, a man from Serbia was physically assaulted by 3 most likely local men in Baska Voda, Croatia. He strongly believes the reason for this assault was the fact he had tattoos of an Orthodox Cross and a Serbian football club. [size=3]
A-HSP: Autochthonous Croatian Party of Rights

On 26 July 2020, the far right A-HSP protested in Srb, Croatia, during the commemoration for the beginning of 'antifascist' resistance in Croatia, claiming the resistance should not be commemorated. [size=no report]

On 26 July 2020, local residents gathered to protest in Zagreb-Trnje, Croatia, during a press conference of a utility company. Earlier in the week, as heavy rain hit Zagreb, no one was present to build the dams and prevent flooding at the utility company. Several citizens broke into the building and built the dams themselves, but were later arrested for breaking and entering. [size=no report]
On 24 July 2020, citizens gathered in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, to protest against the State Prosecutor, claiming the whole office is corrupted. [size=no report]
On 23 July 2020, several dozen law students protested in Split, Croatia, demanding an extra exam term, as one was not held due to the coronavirus. [size=several dozen]
On 18 July 2020, local residents protested in Marcelji, Croatia, in front of a waste disposal site due to environmental concerns. [size=no report]

On 18 July 2020, local residents protested in Koprivnica, Croatia, in solidarity with those who protested in Marcelji that same day against a waste disposal site due to environmental concerns. [size=no report]
On 16 July 2020, local residents protested against the construction of a quarry in Dicmo, Croatia, because of environmental concerns. [size=no report]
On 14 July 2020, several hundred students and professors of marched through Zagreb, Croatia, after the University of Zagreb's rector suspended their faculty's dean. [size=several hundred]
On 10 July 2020, the mayor of Split, Croatia, was attacked first verbally, then physically, by two men who have not yet been identified.
On 10 July 2020, approximately 100 citizens protested in Makarska, Croatia, against the city government and conversion of green surfaces to construction sites. [size=approximately 100]

On 9 July 2020, approximately 100 students and professors of the Faculty in Philosophy in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, protested after the University Rector suspended the Dean of their faculty. [size=approximately 100]

On 9 July 2020, protesters gathered in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, in solidarity with the demonstrations taking place in Serbia. Demonstrations in several cities in Serbia started when the president announced stronger measures against the coronavirus and a weekend-long curfew, weeks after the measures were dropped in order to hold election. [size=no report]
On 8 July 2020, several hundred supporters of the Dinamo football club protested in Zagreb-Maksimir, Croatia, against the club's management. [size=several hundred]

On 3 July 2020, parents of hospitalized children protested in front of the Ministry of Health in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, because they are only allowed to visit their children 15 minutes a day, a measure imposed in order to supress the coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 28 June 2020, approximately 40 local residents protested in Srijane, Croatia, demanding a better reconstruction of a local road. [size=approximately 40]
On 27 June 2020, approximately 300 demonstrators participated in a 'March for Life' against abortion in Rijeka, Croatia. A smaller counter-protest was conducted by RF. [size=approximately 300]
In the Name of the Family

On 20 June 2020, several hundred people associated with In the Name of the Family marched through Sisak, Croatia, demanding a total ban on abortions. A counter-protest was held, calling for full access to health care for women and against 'ultraconservatives'. [size=several hundred]

On 18 June 2020, a police officer beat and injured an Afghani refugee near Slunj, Croatia. The refugee asked for help when his wife was injured crossing the border. The policeman has since been arrested, along with a colleague who was present during the beating and did not stop him.

On 15 June 2020, approximately 200 protesters gathered in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, 'in solidarity with those affected by the earthquake' which hit the city during the coronavirus crisis, and against the city's mayor, demanding a law on rebuilding the city be passed. [size=approximately 200]
On 14 June 2020, locals protested in Omis, Croatia, against further illegal construction in a lagoon. [size=no report]

On 12 June 2020, commercial boat owners protested by sailing from Pula to Fazana, Croatia, against fees they have to pay for a near-by national park. They claimed that this was particularly difficult due to economic pressures from coronavirus. [size=no report]
On 10 June 2020, local residents protested in Dubrovnik, Croatia, against construction in their neighbourhood. [size=no report]
On 9 June 2020, approximately 400 protesters rallied in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and against police brutality. [size=approximately 400]

On 6 June 2020, protesters who had taken out loans in Swiss Franks gathered in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia, demanding those contracts be annulled. The protest was supported by the Human Shield. [size=no report]

On 28 May 2020, about 50 parents protested in front of a school that was damaged in the earthquake in Zagreb-Tresnjevka-jug, Croatia, because the children will have classes in a school that is too far away for them until the building is safe. [size=about 50]

On 26 May 2020, during the night, the Croatian police caught a group of refugees from Pakistan and Afghanistan, around Plitvice lakes, near Slunj, Croatia. They allegedly severely beat them and then rubbed food into the wounds.
On 23 May 2020, approximately 30 people protested against the measures implemented to fight the coronavirus in Dubrovnik, Croatia. They also carried signs against 5G. [size=approximately 30]

Around 22 May 2020, masked men who were armed captured a group of 16 refugees who had crossed into Croatia, capital of which is Zagreb. The attackers beat the refugees severely, shot at them, made death threats, robbed them and then called the police, who then drove the group of refugees into Bosnia and Herzegovina. Though the masked men had no ID or insignia, refugees and activists suspect a they are or are tied with a special police unit, based on previous similar events and them working with uniformed police.

On 21 May 2020, more than 100 business owners mostly from the transport, tourism, and event industry protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, demanding government subsidies to help with their losses due to the coronavirus. [size=more than 100]

On 17 May 2020, approximately 20 people from several organizations including RF, protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, because the parliament was dissolved before adopting an act on the reconstruction of Zagreb after the earthquake. [size=approximately 20]
On 17 May 2020, a protest against 5G and vaccination in the conext of coronavirus was held in Zagreb-Donji Grad, Croatia. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove more than 50 buses in protest in Zadar, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=more than 50 buses]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Rijeka, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Dubrovnik, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Zagreb, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Split, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Sibenik, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no reports]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Pula, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, those working in tourism drove buses in protest in Osijek, Croatia, demanding a moratorium on leasing due to the coronavirus. This was part of a wider European 'Honk for Hope' protest action. [size=no report]

On 14 May 2020, a young Serbian man was physically attacked in Vukovar, Croatia. According to early reports, he was attacked by fans of a football club from Zagreb for his ethnicity. That same day there were reports of someone threatening and intimidating patrons of a restaurant frequented by Serbs. [size=no report]

On 10 May 2020, approximately 50 protesters gathered in Rijeka, Croatia, calling the coronavirus a 'scam' and demanding measures imposed to stop the spread of the virus be lifted. Also present was the former leader of Zivi Zid. [size=approximately 50]
On 8 May 2020, a protest was held in Zagreb-Tresnjevka-jug, Croatia, against the city's mayor and the way 'he has been running the city for almost 20 years'. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding buses in Osijek, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=no report]
On 7 May 2020, approximately 80 workers of a communality company protested in Sibenik, Croatia, against the company management and its treatment of workers. [size=approximately 80]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding buses in Rijeka, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding 47 buses in Split, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=47 buses]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding approximately 50 buses in Dubrovnik, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=approximately 50 buses]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding buses in Varazdin, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding buses in Zadar, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding approximately 60 buses on the Y-highway in Istria, near Kanfanar, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=approximately 60 buses]

On 7 May 2020, approximately 20 oppositional members of city parliament protested in Zagreb-Gornji Grad-Medvescak, Croatia, by sitting together with their laptops because the city parliament session was held online due to coronavirus, when they believed it could be held in person. [size=approximately 20]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding buses in Zagreb, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2020, owners and workers of smaller transport companies protested by riding buses in Pula, Croatia, and demanded a moratorium on leasing as they cannot work due to the coronavirus. This was a synchronised protest in several Croatian cities. [size=no report]

On 1 May 2020, a protest was held in Split, Croatia, against the quarantine measures imposed due to the coronavirus and 5G network, as well as to mark May Day. One protester was arrested for calling a policeman 'comorade'. [size=no report]

On 1 May 2020, approximately 20 people protested in Rijeka, Croatia, against the 5G network and all measures imposed to battle the coronavirus, calling the virus 'a conspiracy'. [size=approximately 20]
On 1 May 2020, a protest was held in Zagreb, Croatia, against the 5G network and all measures imposed to battle the coronavirus, calling the virus 'a conspiracy'. [size=no report]
On 24 April 2020, locals protested in Split, Croatia, while respecting distancing measures, over badly regulated traffic in their area. [size=no report]
On 24 April 2020, residents of Zagreb, Croatia, protested from their balconies and windows against the city's mayor. [size=no report]
On 17 April 2020, citizens in Zagreb, Croatia, protested against the mayor by making noise from their windows and balconies and by honking from their cars. [size=no report]

On 12 April 2020, two female journalists were physically attacked by several men in Split, Croatia, while trying to report on a crowd of church-goers gathering for Easter mass despite government measures against the coronavirus. [size=several]

On 12 April 2020, at least 13 people protested in Split, Croatia, in support of a priest who called worshippers to attend mass on Easter. 13 protesters were later arrested for violating measures against the coronavirus. [size=at least 13]

On 3 April 2020, citizens of Zagreb, Croatia protested from their homes by banging pots and pans together on their balconies against the city's mayor and his response to the recent earthquake. [size=no report]

On 10 March 2020, about a dozen bus drivers and 150 taxi drivers organized a protest ride in Split, Croatia, and blocked traffic because of what they say is unfair competition and liberalization of the taxi market. [size=approximately 160]

On 8 March 2020, protesters marched through Split, Croatia, demanding government to adopt a new National Equality Policy and support the European Strategy for Gender Equality on the occasion of the International Women's Day. [size=no report]
On 8 March 2020, a protest was held in Varazdin, Croatia, against the new city budget. [size=no report]

On 8 March 2020, protesters, including students, marched through Zadar, Croatia, calling for equal rights and payment in the labour market and demonstrating over violence against women on the occasion of the International Women's Day. [size=no report]

On 8 March 2020, approximately 7000 protesters marched through Zagreb, Croatia, calling to end domestic violence against women and violence against migrants at the borders of Europe. [size=approximately 7000]
On 28 February 2020, members of a hockey club protested in Sisak, Croatia, because they don't have access to the ice rink to practice in. [size=no report]
On the night between 24 February and 25 February 2020, residents of Permuda, Croatia, protested demanding 24/7 access to electricity. [size=no report]
On 20 February, a protest was held in Zagreb, Croatia, to mark World Social Justice Day and draw attention to social exclusion of people with disabilities. [size=no report]
On 15 Febuary, a '1 Million Rising' protest against violence against women was held in Zagreb, Croatia. [size=no report]
On 15 February, a protest was held in Zagreb, Croatia, in order to preserve a park and stop it from being used as a construction site. [size=no report]

On 10 February, approximately 1000 veterans protested in Samobor, Croatia, after the Mayor of that city made comments that veterans protesting several years before were 'a few drunks'. [size=approximately 1000]
On 7 February, a protest was held in Dubrovnik, Croatia, against a certain company being allocated funds for waste disposal. [size=no report]
On 6 February, approximately 100 people protested against the new city management plan in Zagreb, Croatia. [size=approximately 100]
On 1 February, around 20,000 protested in Zagreb, Croatia, against the city's mayor Milan Bandic who is under investigation for several corruption allegations. [size=around 20,000]
On 26 January, approximately 50 protesters gathered in Zadar, Croatia, protesting against the shortage of doctors causing 13,000 women not having access to gynecological care. [size=approximately 50]
On 25 January, a protest was held in Dubrovnik, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. [size=no report]
On 25 January, a protest was held in Rovinj, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. [size=no report]
On 25 January, a protest was held in Zadar, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. [size=no report]
On 25 January, a protest was held in Osijek, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. [size=no report]
On 25 January, dozens protested in Zagreb, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. Members of Human Shield attended. [size=dozens]
On 25 January, a protest was held in Karlovac, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. [size=no report]
On 25 January, a protest was held in Rijeka, Croatia, against the introduction of the 5G network. [size=no report]

On 23 January, approximately 50 protesters marched through Split, Croatia, demanding a change in the justice system, after a man killed three people two weeks ago. They claim the system failed him and drove him to the murders. [size=approximately 50]
On 22 January, a protest was held in Zagreb, Croatia, against the mayor who is on trial for corruption. [size=no report]
On 15 January, former workers of a bankrupt bus company protested in Zadar, Croatia, demanding their severance packages be paid. [size=no report]
On 04 January, approximately 1000 protested against the city's mayor in Zagreb, Croatia [size=approximately 1000]
SDP: Social Democratic Party of Croatia
On 03 January, a member of the oppositional SDP was physically attacked in Zadar, Croatia while putting up posters for the upcoming presidential elections. One person was arrested later that night.
On 21 December, more than 1000 protested in the Croatian capital Zagreb against the city's Mayor, who is under investigation for multiple corruption allegations [size=more than 1000].
On 20 December, approximately 200 high school students protested in Rijeka, Croatia after their Religious Studies teacher was transferred to another school [size=approximately 200].

On 19 December, employees of the 'Srebrnjak' children's hospital protested in Zagreb, Croatia to show support for the hospital director who was fired amid accusations of quackery, claiming the accusations are false [size=no report]
On 18 December, social work students protested in Osijek, Croatia because, as they say, the program still lack necessary accreditation two years after it began [size=no report]
On December 09, approximately 70 activists protested in Zagreb, Croatia, against the city's waste disposal deal and against the Mayor, claiming he is corrupt. [size=approximately 70]
On December 09, a group of high school students protested in Zagreb, Croatia, against recent education reforms. [size=no report]

On December 05, approximately 20 friends and family protested in Osijek, Croatia, in support of a local man who had been convicted of sexual abuse of his 5-year-old sister, claiming he is innocent. [size=approximately 20].
On December 04, parents and carers of children with disabilities protested in Zagreb, Croatia, demanding bigger compensation for their labour. [size=no report]
On December 03, around 200 people protested in Zagreb, Croatia, against the increase of the price of waste disposal and bad waste management in the city. [size=around 200]
On November 29, a protest was held in Zagreb, Croatia, demanding urgent measures to prevent climate change after the EP declared a climate emergency. [size=no report]
On November 29, workers of a mechanical engineering company, supported by local teachers, protested in Slavonski Brod, Croatia because their salaries are late. [size=no report]
On November 28, workers of a mechanical engineering company, supported by local teachers, protested in Slavonski Brod, Croatia, because their salaries are late. [size=no report]
On November 25, several hundred teachers protested in Osijek, Croatia, in support of the bigger protest in the capital that same day. [size=several hundred]
On November 25, around 20,000 teachers protested in Zagreb, Croatia, demanding higher salaries. They have been on strike for a month. [size=around 20,000]
On November 23, a group of war veterans and supporters gathered in Sisak, Croatia, after a 1990s war memorial was vandalized in that city. [size=no report]

On November 23, approximately 20 protesters gathered in Zadar, Croatia, in support of a policeman who was suspended after he released footage of the deputy chief of police exceeding the speed limit. [size=approximately 20]

On November 23, approximately 50 citizens protested in Virovitica demanding an investigation into the death of the city's financial manager earlier this year. He was found dead after an apparent suicide hours before news broke out of public funds going missing, for which the Mayor publicly blamed him, though didn't investigate further. [size=approximately 50]
On November 21, about 300 teachers protested in the Croatian capital, Zagreb. They have been on strike for weeks and are demanding higher salaries [size=about 300]

On November 20, about 100 members of education unions stood along the main streets of Zagreb, Croatia holding signs for drivers with 'Honk for education' written on them. Teachers have been on strike in Croatia for weeks now. The European People's Party congress was taking place in Zagreb that day. [size=about 100]
On November 14, local residents protested in Sibenik, Croatia, against docking stations being installed without their permission. [size=no report]
On November 11, hundreds of workers of an agricultural industry protested in Vinkovci, Croatia saying they might lose their jobs if new law regulating land ownership is passed. [size=hundreds]
On November 6, about 2000 teachers and educators protested in the Croatian capital Zagreb, demanding higher salaries. [size=about 2000]

On February 15, 2018 in Croatian city of Pula citizens protested against privatization of Uljanik shipyard. The protest was organized by the 'Workers' Front' under the 'Initiative for the Defense of Uljanik'.

On February 12, 2018 protesters gathered in the center of Zagreb, Croatia, in Ban Jelacic Square, expressing dissatisfaction over the visit of Serbian president Aleksandar Vucic. Protest was led by the war veterans from the conflict in the 1990s and war veterans' widows.

On February 10, 2018 in Zagreb, Croatia, a protest named 'Handmaids Rising' was organized urging the government to ratify the Istanbul Convention as a framework for the improvement of the status of women and tool for their more efficient protection.

On February 3, 2018 in Karlovac, Croatia citizens protested expressing dissatisfaction with the general living conditions in the country, including low life standard of pensioners and high numbers of those working in public administration.
On February 1, 2018 in Zagreb, Croatia the Workers' Front and the representatives of the Croatian left, joined by workers of several bankrupt companies protested over workers' rights.

On January 29, 2018, Croatian authorities started fining Slovenian fishermen fishing in the disputed territory of Savudrija Bay in response to Slovenian authorities fined Croatian fishermen fishing there.
On January 23, 2018, workers of Pula-based Uljanik shipyard in Croatia gathered in front of the administration building of the shipyard, demanding the management's resignation.
On January 22, 2018, approximately a hundred of workers of Pula-based Uljanik shipyard gathered in front of the administration building of the shipyard, demanding the management's resignation.
On January 19, 2018 in Zadar, Croatia, a bomb exploded in front of a private house.
On January 17, 2018 in Rijeka, Croatia, two fractions of workers' union representatives clashed over legitimacy of each fraction, to which the police intervened.

On January 15, 2018, a group of handball fans from Montenegro was attacked in Zagreb, Croatia's capital, which hosted the European Men's Handball Championship. The incident happened after the match between Montenegro and Macedonia.
On January 13, 2018 in Otocac, Croatia, residents protested over the decision of the local administration to abolish the local radio station in order to save funds.

On January 11, 2018, in Graberje, Croatia, a backpack with 60 pieces of ammunition and a bomb have been found, as well as an unexploded hand grenade in Slabinja. Police officers removed the explosives.

Widows of Croatian war veterans from the 1990s conflict protested in front of the headquarters of the public broadcaster in Zagreb, Croatia on January 11, 2018. The widows protested against the broadcasting of a movie whose plot involved pension fraud on part of the fictional widows of war veterans.

On January 7, 2018, representatives of Croatian 'Workers Front' and Slovenian 'Left' met at the Dragonja river border between the two countries to protest their government's clashes over Pirana Bay, claiming that those serve to distract the population from urgent economic issues.
